body: @aeaversa I like your suggestion of allowing them to begin making configuration changes right away while waiting. Your proposed design sounds good. One think I would caution against is including too many co-located buttons and/or swapping/removing buttons under certain conditions. I don't think you're suggesting we do this, but without seeing something I only want to mention it to avoid a potentially confusing experience. Look forward to seeing this in action and providing some design critique.
@moranr - Thanks Rob!  Should have a fresh commit out on the PR in a few days and look forward to hearing your suggestions when you can take a test drive.
Reviewing...

@aeaversa @moranr I'm definitely not opposed to the idea's here. Just wanted to offer a few thoughts.

Currently, we cannot open the Configure dialog while there are still active threads. This path forward moves away from that. We'd likely want to update the Configure context menu availability as well. The one benefit the current solution offers, however, is that if the processor is reporting any issues they are available via its bulletins. If we already have the Configuration dialog open there would be no way to see these. This is something that I hadn't even considered during my previous comments. We could also make these bulletins available, in addition to the active threads, but I wonder if it starts to get too muddled all in the Configuration dialog.

Not sure, maybe it's not necessary. Thoughts? 

Also looking forward to checking it out.
Reviewing...

> The code LGTM, I'm not able to give it a try right now unfortunately. Just one question though: does it take care of the ticket renewal? or is the underlying implementation taking care of it? (asking since the client is initialized in the OnScheduled method)

UGI will take care of the relogin, but I think only if the UGI.doAs is used to execute the action.  If the PR is updated to use KerberosAction from nifi-security-utils org.apache.nifi.security.krb.KerberosAction, it will handle expired tickets.
Reviewing...
@mcgilman - I definitely see your point. It really would be nice to have the bulletins available for the processor on the dialog. I'll look into it as I refactor.
Code looks good and verified that flow files are swapped in and out correctly while the application is running and during restarts, going to merge, thanks!
rebased.

Thanks Matt, the changes are pushed now.

We can always make the HEALTHCHECK call a shell script that does more robust environment checking. I think there are a pair of mutually exclusive environment variables that can be tested to determine if we're SSL or not. I always try to start with a cute one-liner 😉 

A better endpoint for a heartbeat is also fine. I figured the landing page is as good as any without an endpoint specifically configured to return detailed health info.
Come to think of it, I think it needs more testing before opening a PR. That said, got approval to release today.
Looks good, going to merge
Will review...
Thanks @patricker! Definitely a good catch and happy to see it make it in for 1.9.0. I have merged this to master.
@alopresto How are we looking for this one now? Are there any remaining changes I need to make?

+1 LGTM, ran full unit and integration tests, and tried on a live NiFi instance with Avro and CSV data. I also tried with the JsonTreeReader and invalid JSON, they appear to throw a checked exception so the error was already handled correctly, no need to add these fixes to that reader ATM.  Thanks for the fix! Merging to master
There were some checkstyle problems on unused imports, but I fixed those. Ran `contrib-check` and all tests pass. +1, merging.
Looks like @joewitt took care of this. I noticed a couple (existing) issues with formatting, so I'll open a new Jira for that.

Could someone take a look at this?

Cheers
Functionality looks good, so I'm ready to merge this PR after the NOTICE update has been made.

Thanks, @mattyb149!  Reviewed and tested your changes after your last commit.  Looks good!  I updated the Hive_1_1ConnectionPoolTest.testKerberosAuthException test to use a mocked KerberosCredentialsService.

+1, merged to master!

Mans
@patricker  @bbende anything left to be done here or can we merge?
@zenfenan @mattyb149 anyone?

@Bright-Liu it might be a good idea for you to turn this into an independent project and advertise it to the community on the user list instead. We're starting to hit a point where the committers and PMC are having a hard time keeping up with the breadth of requests for new systems in terms of being able to understand them well enough to officially support them.

If you'd like some help in turning this into an independent package, I can point you in the right direction and get you started.
Looks good to me, going to merge

thanks mark - verifying now
it does not appear to solve the problem.  That said I'm not quite sure I follow what the test was trying to do.  It just picks the 100th item and adds sleep?
+1 LGTM, tested with CSV and JSON readers with various property settings and inputs. Thanks for this great contribution! Merging to master
Reviewing...

Thanks for the updates and this contribution, @markap14!

Tested this against a kerberized cluster (HDFS, Impala, Kudu), creating Impala tables stored in Kudu, inserting data into Kudu with the PutKudu processor configured to use a KerberosCredentialsService.

LGTM, +1.  Merging to master!
@mattyb149 Everything should be in order based on your feedback now.

@markap14 If you get a change to review this, that would be much appreciated! I have verified the fix manually. The steps to reproduce the issue this addresses are on the Jira: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-5950
Reviewing...
@MikeThomsen @bbende I see you have done much HBase work here. can you guys please review this when you get free time?

Ok so the code Kevin provided works, passes tests & checkstyle. I made some additional [refactoring changes](https://github.com/alopresto/nifi/commits/pr3301) available in a branch on my fork. I am a +1 for the PR as it is here if it needs to be merged immediately without my refactoring being reviewed, but I think I cleaned up the duplicated code and made it easier to follow (understanding that Kevin was just trying to get a fix for the issue in). If @kevdoran or @markap14 want to review that, I will handle the rebasing & merging tomorrow.

Thanks @alopresto. Unfortunately, I don't have any more additional time to spend on this issue until after the 1.9.0 release (as it was, it took up significantly more time than I anticipated and I have a backlog of other items folks are waiting on). 

When looking at the code to plan the fix, @markap14 and I did notice some things that could be refactored for code de-duplication and to break this class file up a little bit, so maybe that is a larger effort that could be addressed after 1.9.0, using your branch as a starting point.

@mcgilman @moranr - I went ahead and updated the code to allow the Processor Configuration/Details dialog(s) to support the display of threads and bulletins in the same style as is displayed on the processors on the canvas. A terminate prompt is on the Processor Configuration dialog "Apply" button as well, such that should the end user hit "Apply" and threads are still active, it will simply provide them an option to terminate or wait for the threads to finish normally. I believe this is a good solution to allow threads to naturally close out in the background as the user is making their changes. I did not institute an additional polling process to inspect the thread state, but rather simply synced the thread state value off the current canvas value for the component, since that interface already has a polling process active. Additionally, per @mcgilman suggestion, I added the Stop & Configure option to the context menu as well. Please take a test drive and let me know your feedback whenever you guys get a chance. My thanks again for all your help with this.
Reviewing...
+1 LGTM, tested several formats and queries, all looks good. Thanks for this improvement! Merging to master
Thanks @bbende. I'll try to find some time to work on that and get those things addressed.

Thank you @jtstorck, I made changes.

- Reverted `FsPermission permission = FsCreateModes.applyUMask(FsPermission.getFileDefault(), FsPermission.getUMask(configuration));`
- Make tests separated

For now tests fails because of the revert, but it works on live Hadoop environment.
+1, merged to master, thanks @mattyb149
Also I tested the PR and I can confirm it's working (with the above mentioned caveats) on a two node cluster.
Saw that some tests were failing the continuous integration checks and re-based to current master.
Will review...

Hey @patricker sorry for the delay in getting back to this. I looked into the unit tests, and did some quick profiling. It looks like the reason that it seemed to "go out to lunch" as you say was because of Mockito objects being used. They are super useful but don't provide great performance. I updated the test so that instead of using Mockito it just created simple objects like Funnels or implemented interfaces directly without much of anything happening. That resulted in much better performance.

I updated the test about to run in multiple threads, as well, because this is where we are going to see the heavy contention and therefore the performance concerns. When I run with a single thread, we see pretty comparable results between the existing implementation and the new implementation that checks for penalization:

> 1M checks for FlowFiles, non-empty queue: 57 millis
> --------------------
> 1M checks for FlowFiles, non-penalized method, non-empty queue: 101 millis

> --------------------

> --------------------

> --------------------

So with 12 threads, each checking 1 million times, the difference in performance/latency goes from 2-3 seconds to 70-90 seconds.

We can also see what happens to the CPU utilization as it switches between the version that checks penalization and the one that doesn't:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/184268/52737399-3e684280-2f9a-11e9-94f7-6231a6077959.png)

So at one thread, I'm not concerned about the performance difference. But if you start adding several threads to a processor, the performance concern is definitely more significant and I think is concerning.

@kei-miyauchi I've updated the permission tests in PutHDFSTest so that the mock filesystem has the correct Hadoop configuration, which fixes the tests.  I'm going to do some final live HDFS testing, and then I'll merge your PR with my updates.

Hit a similar issue when attempting to view the policy under these same conditions. Filed a JIRA for addressing it [1].

Recommend hiding whitespace changes for this PR (setting under "Diff Settings" or via [link here](https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/3305/files?utf8=%E2%9C%93&diff=unified&w=1)).

Tests against real HDFS cluster worked:
* umask configured in the processor
* no umask in the processor, custom umask value hdfs-site.xml `fs.permissions.umask-mode` property defined in hdfs-site.xml
* no umask in processor or hdfs-site.xml `fs.permissions.umask-mode` property, fallback to Hadoop default 022

@mosermw Thanks for the PR. According to the OpenId Connect specification, the scope parameter with a value of `openid` is required [1]. Additional scopes can be used and should be ignored if unrecognized.

I think the docs for ForgeRock [2] also discuss requiring the `openid` scope.

[1] https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AuthRequest
[2] https://backstage.forgerock.com/docs/am/6/oidc1-guide/#register-openid-connect-clients

+1 LGTM, ran tests and tried on a live NiFi instance, verified I could create a table from the generated DDL atop the converted ORC file. Also verified the new IllegalArgumentException code is reached (and the flow file sent to failure) using 'fixed' Avro type (we'll need a separate Jira to support that).

Thanks for the fix! Merging to master

Hey @mcgilman thanks for looking at this!

It's not the Authorization Request that's failing, and you're correct that one must have a scope.  In this case it's the Token Request [1] that's failing.

[1] - https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#TokenRequest

@mosermw Bah. Sorry was so focused on the scope removal I didn't process the context of the change. Glancing at the docs, I'm also not seeing why we're using the `scope` parameter in the token request. I'll take another look and see if I can't remember why that ended up there in the first place.
Thanks @mosermw! This has been merged to master.

> def agree we are struggling to keep up. but fellow apache projects we should open arms to.

That way it could be released whenever they want to the NiFi community and their own users and they could iterate as aggressively as they want under their own release policies.

@joewitt yes, it was verified:

changed the kernel configs to aggressive values, and started a build:
- without this fix: the connection lingered / as OS keepalive was not allowed to garbage collect it
- with the fix: the connection disappeared as OS level keepalive could do it's thing
